title: HST Affiliated Faculty
summary: Ziv Williams is an Associate Professor affiliated with the Harvard-MIT Health Sciences and Technology (HST) program, where he contributes significantly to the understanding of complex cognition across various species, including humans, monkeys, and mice.
fullText: Ziv Williams is an Associate Professor affiliated with the Harvard-MIT Health Sciences and Technology (HST) program, where he contributes significantly to the understanding of complex cognition across various species, including humans, monkeys, and mice. With a robust background in neuroscience, Dr. Williams specializes in neural prosthetics and functional restoration, utilizing advanced techniques such as deep brain stimulation and neural modeling to explore and enhance cognitive functions. His work aims to bridge the gap between theoretical neuroscience and practical applications, addressing critical challenges in brain health and rehabilitation. Dr. Williams's research focuses on the intricate mechanisms of cognition and the potential for technological interventions in neurological disorders. His expertise in neural prosthetics positions him at the forefront of developing innovative solutions for restoring lost functionalities in patients with brain injuries or neurodegenerative diseases. By employing cross-species comparisons, he aims to uncover fundamental principles of neural processing and apply these insights to improve therapeutic strategies. His contributions to the fields of neuroscience and biomedical engineering reflect a commitment to advancing our understanding of the brain and developing impactful technologies for patient care.
dlc: Harvard-MIT Program in Health Sciences and Technology

title: Associate Professor of Mathematics
summary: Yufei Zhao is an Associate Professor of Mathematics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), where he is recognized for his contributions to the field of combinatorics and graph theory.
fullText: Yufei Zhao is an Associate Professor of Mathematics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), where he is recognized for his contributions to the field of combinatorics and graph theory. With a strong commitment to academic excellence, Professor Zhao engages in innovative research that addresses fundamental problems in discrete mathematics, often employing advanced techniques to explore the interplay between combinatorial structures and their applications in computer science. In his role at MIT, Professor Zhao has made significant strides in understanding various combinatorial phenomena, enhancing the mathematical community's grasp of complex systems. His research interests include extremal graph theory, random graphs, and the application of probabilistic methods to combinatorial problems. Zhao's work not only contributes to theoretical advancements but also has practical implications in areas such as algorithm design and network analysis, showcasing his expertise in both theoretical and applied mathematics. Through his research and teaching, he continues to inspire the next generation of mathematicians and fosters collaboration across disciplines.
dlc: Department of Mathematics

title: Alfred Henry (1929) and Jean Morrison Hayes Career Development Assistant Professor of Electrical Engineering
summary: Sixian You serves as the Alfred Henry (1929) and Jean Morrison Hayes Career Development Assistant Professor of Electrical Engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT).
fullText: Sixian You serves as the Alfred Henry (1929) and Jean Morrison Hayes Career Development Assistant Professor of Electrical Engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT). In this role, he combines his extensive expertise in biological and medical devices and systems with advanced knowledge in electronic, magnetic, optical, and quantum materials and devices. His position at MIT allows him to contribute to the development of innovative technologies that bridge the gap between engineering and health care. Dr. You's research focuses on the design and application of cutting-edge devices and systems that harness the principles of optics and photonics. He is dedicated to advancing the field through his work on novel materials and device architectures that facilitate breakthroughs in medical diagnostics and treatment. His contributions are critical in enhancing the performance and functionality of devices that operate at the intersection of biology and engineering, ultimately aiming to improve patient outcomes and drive technological progress in the medical sector.

title: Breene M Kerr (1951) Professor of Nuclear Science and Engineering
summary: Yildiz Group's research focuses on laying the scientific groundwork and proof-of-principle material systems for the next generation of high-efficiency devices for energy conversion and information processing, based on solid state ionic-electronic material
fullText: Bilge Yildiz is the Breene M Kerr (1951) Professor of Nuclear Science and Engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), located in Cambridge, Massachusetts. With a distinguished career as a full professor, Yildiz has established herself as a leading expert in the fields of electrochemical materials and interfaces. Her extensive knowledge encompasses a wide range of topics, including electrochemical energy conversion through fuel cells and electrolyzers, as well as the development of advanced membranes and solid-state batteries for energy storage. At the helm of the Yildiz Group, she focuses on pioneering research that lays the scientific foundation for next-generation high-efficiency devices, particularly in the realms of energy conversion and information processing. Her work emphasizes the use of solid-state ionic-electronic materials, driving innovations in neuromorphic computing and redox-based memristive information storage. Through her research, Yildiz aims to address critical challenges in energy efficiency and information technology, contributing significantly to the advancement of sustainable energy solutions and cutting-edge computing materials.
tags: Electrochemical Energy Conversion by Fuel Cells
Electrochemical Energy Storage by Solid State Batteries
Redox Based Memristive Information Storage and
dlc: Department of Nuclear Science and Engineering

title: Principal Research Scientist
summary: Magnetic Fusion: Heating, current drive, and transport, in toroidal devices, induced by radio frequency waves (ion cyclotron, lower hybrid, and electron cyclotron). Parametric wave processes in the plasma edge. Inertial Confinement Fusion: Laser-plasm
fullText: Abhay Ram serves as a Principal Research Scientist at MIT, where he specializes in the intricate field of magnetic fusion energy and inertial confinement fusion. With extensive expertise in electromagnetic wave-plasma interactions, he is at the forefront of research that explores heating, current drive, and transport mechanisms in toroidal devices, specifically through the application of radio frequency waves such as ion cyclotron, lower hybrid, and electron cyclotron. His work is pivotal in advancing the understanding of parametric wave processes occurring at the plasma edge, which are crucial for the development of efficient fusion systems. Dr. Ram's contributions to the field encompass a broad spectrum of key areas, including radiofrequency heating, wave scattering, nonlinear dynamics, and wave-particle interactions in plasmas. Through his research, he aims to enhance the performance of fusion devices and lay the groundwork for future breakthroughs in sustainable energy generation. His innovative studies not only contribute to the scientific community but also align with MIT's mission to address global energy challenges through cutting-edge technological advancements.
dlc: Plasma Science and Fusion Center

title: Senior Research Scientist
summary: Paul Bonoli specializes in theoretical and computational plasma physics in the areas of radio-frequency (RF) heating and current drive in toroidal confinement devices (tokamaks). He has developed detailed simulation models for RF heating and current drive
fullText: Paul Bonoli serves as a Senior Research Scientist at MIT, where he specializes in theoretical and computational plasma physics. With a keen focus on radio-frequency (RF) heating and current drive mechanisms in toroidal confinement devices, particularly tokamaks, he has made significant contributions to understanding and optimizing plasma behavior in fusion energy research. His work is essential in advancing the capabilities of tokamak systems, which are critical for developing sustainable fusion energy solutions. Bonoli's research is primarily centered around developing detailed simulation models that elucidate RF heating and current drive processes. His expertise lies in high-performance computing simulations of RF wave-particle interactions, allowing for precise theoretical predictions and computational analyses. Through his innovative approach and deep understanding of radio-frequency wave-particle interactions, Bonoli has contributed to the broader scientific community's efforts to enhance plasma confinement and stability in fusion reactors. His work not only supports ongoing research initiatives at MIT but also positions him as a key player in the field of plasma physics and fusion energy development.
tags: High Performance Computing Simulations of RF - Wave Particle Interactions
Theory and Computation of Radio-Frequency Wave-Particle Interactions
dlc: Plasma Science and Fusion Center

title: Principal Research Scientist
summary: Dr. Wright has been interested in fusion since his days as an undergraduate in the Applied Physics program at Columbia University. He received his PhD in Astrophysics at the Princeton Plasma Physics Laboratory and served a post-doc in the Physics Departme
fullText: Dr. John Wright is a Principal Research Scientist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), where he leverages his extensive knowledge in radiofrequency systems and multiphysics modeling to advance the field of fusion energy. With a deep-rooted passion for fusion that began during his undergraduate studies in Applied Physics at Columbia University, Dr. Wright has dedicated his career to exploring innovative solutions for energy production. His academic journey culminated in a PhD in Astrophysics from the prestigious Princeton Plasma Physics Laboratory, followed by a post-doctoral fellowship in the Physics Department, further enhancing his expertise in the intricate dynamics of plasma physics. Throughout his career, Dr. Wright has made significant contributions to the understanding and development of radiofrequency technologies in fusion applications. His research focuses on the intricate modeling of RF systems, which are critical for plasma heating and stability in fusion reactors. With a strong command of both theoretical and practical aspects of multiphysics modeling, he has been instrumental in developing cutting-edge approaches that address complex challenges in fusion energy. Dr. Wright's work not only contributes to the scientific community but also aims to pave the way for sustainable and efficient energy solutions for the future.
dlc: Plasma Science and Fusion Center

title: Research Scientist
summary: Darin Ernst is a Research Scientist at MIT, specializing in the fields of physics research and fusion theory and computation.
fullText: Darin Ernst is a Research Scientist at MIT, specializing in the fields of physics research and fusion theory and computation. With a robust background in magnetic fusion plasmas, he has made significant contributions to the understanding of complex plasma behavior and the fundamental processes that govern fusion energy. His work is essential in advancing the knowledge required for developing viable fusion energy solutions, which have the potential to provide a sustainable and clean energy source for the future. Dr. Ernst's research focuses on several key areas, including the theory and simulation of turbulence, internal transport barriers, plasma rotation, and electric fields. He has been actively involved with the Alcator C-Mod project, where he investigates the dynamics of zonal flows and neoclassical transport phenomena. His expertise extends to the effects of radiation on plasma behavior, further enhancing the understanding of how to optimize plasma confinement and stability in fusion reactors. Through his innovative research and collaboration with fellow scientists, Darin Ernst continues to contribute to the advancement of fusion science and technology.
tags: Neoclassical Transport in Magnetic Fusion Plasmas
dlc: Plasma Science and Fusion Center

title: Research Affiliate
summary: Martin Greenwald is a Research Affiliate at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), where he leverages his extensive expertise in plasma turbulence and fusion energy.
fullText: Martin Greenwald is a Research Affiliate at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), where he leverages his extensive expertise in plasma turbulence and fusion energy. With a distinguished background in plasma physics, he is a leading figure in the study of magnetic confinement fusion, focusing on the complex interactions of turbulence and transport phenomena within plasma systems. His work is integral to advancing the understanding of fusion processes, aiming to enhance the efficiency and viability of fusion energy as a sustainable power source. Throughout his career, Greenwald has made significant contributions to the field of plasma physics, particularly in the areas of data management and computing related to fusion research. His research addresses critical challenges in plasma behavior, providing insights that are essential for the development of next-generation fusion reactors. By utilizing advanced computational techniques and data analysis methods, he continues to push the boundaries of knowledge in turbulence dynamics, positioning himself as a pivotal contributor to the future of clean energy solutions through fusion technology.

fullText: Richard Petrasso is a Senior Research Scientist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), where he specializes in the fields of inertial confinement fusion, plasma diagnostics, high-energy-density physics, and laboratory astrophysics. With a distinguished career dedicated to advancing our understanding of complex physical phenomena, Dr. Petrasso has made significant contributions to both theoretical and experimental research in these critical areas. His work is characterized by a commitment to exploring the fundamental principles governing plasma behavior under extreme conditions, which is essential for both energy production and astrophysical applications. Throughout his tenure at MIT, Dr. Petrasso has been instrumental in developing innovative diagnostic techniques and experimental methodologies that enhance the study of high-energy-density plasmas. His research has led to pivotal advancements in inertial confinement fusion, contributing to the broader objective of achieving sustainable fusion energy. By bridging the gap between laboratory experiments and astrophysical processes, he has not only advanced scientific knowledge but has also fostered collaborations that extend the impact of his work beyond academic research. Dr. Petrasso continues to be a leading figure in his field, driving forward the boundaries of what is possible in high-energy-density physics and its applications.

title: Senior Scientist and Department Chair, Physical Oceanography
summary: Robert Weller is a Senior Scientist and Department Chair in Physical Oceanography at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), located in Woods Hole, Massachusetts.
fullText: Robert Weller is a Senior Scientist and Department Chair in Physical Oceanography at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), located in Woods Hole, Massachusetts. With a distinguished career spanning several decades, he is recognized for his expertise in wind-forced motion in the upper ocean, mixed layer dynamics, and the study of upper ocean velocity structures. His innovative research has significantly contributed to the understanding of air-sea interactions and has played a pivotal role in advancing the field of oceanography. Dr. Weller's work encompasses the development of current meters and surface meteorological instrumentation, which are essential for conducting comprehensive air-sea experiments. His investigations into air-sea fluxes have provided valuable insights into the exchange processes between the ocean and atmosphere, enhancing the scientific community's ability to predict and model climate variability. Through his leadership and research contributions, he continues to influence both academic and practical applications in oceanographic sciences, making him a prominent figure in the field.
tags: Wind-Forced Motion in the Upper Ocean
Development of Current Meters and Surface Meteorological Instrumentation for Air/Sea Experiments
dlc: MIT/Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution (WHOI) Joint Program

title: Senior Scientist and Department Chair, Applied Ocean Physics and Engineering (AOPE)
summary: John Trowbridge serves as the Senior Scientist and Department Chair of Applied Ocean Physics and Engineering (AOPE) at MIT.
fullText: John Trowbridge serves as the Senior Scientist and Department Chair of Applied Ocean Physics and Engineering (AOPE) at MIT. With a distinguished career in oceanographic research, he brings a wealth of knowledge and expertise to his role, focusing on the mechanics of geophysical boundary layers and sediment transport. His leadership in the department is characterized by a commitment to advancing the understanding of complex ocean processes, particularly in the context of shelf, estuarine, and nearshore environments. Dr. Trowbridge's research contributions have significantly enhanced the field's understanding of sediment dynamics and their implications for coastal ecosystems. His work investigates the interactions between hydrodynamic forces and sediment movement, providing critical insights that inform both scientific inquiry and practical applications in marine engineering and environmental management. With a keen focus on the intricacies of ocean processes, Trowbridge continues to push the boundaries of knowledge in applied ocean physics, fostering collaboration and innovation within the academic and broader scientific communities.

title: Robert A Swanson (1969) Career Development Associate Professor of Life Sciences
summary: The Vos Lab studies how transcription and genome organization are physically coupled using structural biology and biochemistry. This includes X-ray crystallography, cryo-EM, and biophysical approaches. Professor Vos uses X-ray crystallography, cryo-ele
fullText: Seychelle Vos is the Robert A. Swanson (1969) Career Development Associate Professor of Life Sciences at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT). In her role, she is dedicated to advancing the field of life sciences through her expertise in structural biology and biochemistry. Professor Vos is an esteemed educator and researcher, committed to fostering the next generation of scientists while contributing to the understanding of complex biological systems. The Vos Lab, under her leadership, focuses on elucidating the intricate relationship between transcription processes and genome organization. Utilizing cutting-edge techniques such as X-ray crystallography, cryo-electron microscopy (cryo-EM), and various biophysical approaches, her research aims to uncover the physical coupling mechanisms that govern gene expression and chromosomal dynamics. Professor Vos's work not only enhances our fundamental understanding of cellular processes but also has potential implications for therapeutic strategies in addressing genetic disorders and diseases. Through her innovative research and commitment to excellence, she continues to make significant contributions to the life sciences community at MIT and beyond.
dlc: Department of Biology

title: Clarence J Lebel Professor in Electrical Engineering
summary: Although he joined the Electrical Engineering and Computer Science department in Fall 2006, Professor Palacios has been working on wide bandgap semiconductors for the last 8 years. These semiconductors are, probably, the most complete semiconductor family
fullText: Tomas Palacios is the Clarence J. Lebel Professor in Electrical Engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where he has been a faculty member in the Electrical Engineering and Computer Science department since Fall 2006. With a deep commitment to advancing the field of semiconductor technology, Professor Palacios specializes in the design, processing, and characterization of novel electronic devices, particularly those utilizing wide bandgap semiconductors and graphene. His research is instrumental in exploring the diverse capabilities of wide bandgap semiconductor materials, which are considered the most comprehensive semiconductor family due to their exceptional electronic and optoelectronic properties. Over the past eight years, Professor Palacios has focused on the development of advanced transistors, including MOSFETs, MESFETs, MISFETs, JFETs, HEMTs, MODFETs, and HFETs, utilizing materials such as gallium nitride (GaN), aluminum gallium nitride (AlGaN), aluminum nitride (AlN), and indium gallium nitride (InGaN). His work not only contributes to the theoretical understanding of these materials but also has significant implications for practical applications in high-performance electronic devices. By pushing the boundaries of semiconductor technology, Professor Palacios is at the forefront of innovations that promise to enhance the efficiency and capability of modern electronics, solidifying his reputation as a leading expert in the field.
tags: Processing and Characterization of Novel Electronic Devices in Wide Bandgap Semiconductors and Graphene
dlc: Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science

With a strong foundation in the study of supernovae, neutron stars, and black holes, Matthew plays an integral role in facilitating advanced scientific projects that push the boundaries of current astrophysical understanding. Matthew's expertise lies in the intersection of observational and theoretical astrophysics, particularly in the dynamics and evolution of high-energy events in the universe. title: Research Scientist
summary: Dr. Audenaert is a Research Scientist at MIT. He previously co-founded the company Yellowleaf, a digital agency, and co-led the company for nearly eight years, after which it was successfully acquired by an industry partner. He is passionate about using t
fullText: Dr. Jeroen Audenaert is a Research Scientist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), where he leverages his extensive expertise in machine learning, artificial intelligence, and astrophysics. With a strong foundation in asteroseismology and the study of variable stars, Dr. Audenaert is dedicated to advancing the understanding of stellar structures and behaviors through innovative computational techniques. His research aims to bridge the gap between complex astronomical data and actionable insights, contributing significantly to the field of astrophysics. Prior to his current role at MIT, Dr. Audenaert co-founded Yellowleaf, a digital agency that focused on integrating technology and creativity. Under his leadership, the company thrived for nearly eight years before being successfully acquired by an industry partner. This entrepreneurial experience has equipped him with a unique perspective on the application of advanced technologies in various domains. Dr. Audenaert's multidisciplinary background and his passion for harnessing machine learning and AI in scientific research position him as a valuable asset to both the academic and corporate communities.
dlc: MIT Kavli Institute for Astrophysics and Space Research

title: Research Scientist
summary: David Principe's research is focused on multiwavelength observations of young stars and their planet-forming disks. He reduces and analyzes data from telescopes sensitive to emission in the radio, infrared, optical, and X-ray wavelengths to investigate wh
fullText: David Principe is a Research Scientist at MIT, specializing in the multiwavelength observation of young stars and their planet-forming disks. His work integrates data across various wavelengths, including radio, infrared, optical, and X-ray, to deepen the understanding of star formation processes and the environments in which planets are born. With a passion for uncovering the complexities of high-energy astrophysics, Principe leverages his expertise to analyze and interpret intricate data sets from leading telescopes, contributing significantly to the field of astrophysics. Principe's research not only enhances the scientific community's comprehension of stellar evolution but also informs broader discussions about planetary system formation. His proficiency with advanced observational tools, such as the Chandra X-ray Observatory and Magellan telescopes, underscores his commitment to high-precision astronomy. As a recognized expert in star formation and high-energy astrophysics, David Principe continues to push the boundaries of our knowledge, making valuable contributions to both academic research and practical applications in the study of the universe.
dlc: MIT Kavli Institute for Astrophysics and Space Research

title: David Austin Professor of Management
summary: Professor Aral’s ground-breaking study on the spread of fake news (The spread of true and false news online) was featured on the cover of Science in March 2018 and shared broadly across global media. His most recent research will be published in September
fullText: Sinan Aral is the David Austin Professor of Management at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), where he is recognized for his pioneering research in the fields of information technology, social contagion, and product virality. As a full professor, he combines rigorous academic inquiry with practical insights, focusing on how information spreads through social networks and its implications for consumer behavior and productivity in the digital age. Professor Aral gained international acclaim for his groundbreaking study on the spread of true and false news online, which was featured on the cover of Science in March 2018 and has since been widely disseminated across global media outlets. His research not only contributes to the understanding of social dynamics in the digital landscape but also informs strategies for managing information and consumer demand effectively. With his expertise spanning diverse areas including social networks, information worker productivity, and the measurement of social phenomena, Professor Aral continues to shape the discourse on how technology influences society and business. His most recent research is set to be published in September, further solidifying his role as a thought leader in the field.
dlc: MIT Sloan School of Management

title: AMAX Career Development Assistant Professor in Materials Engineering
summary: Professor Cheema joined the MIT Department of Materials Science and Engineering, with a joint appointment in the Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science (EECS), as an assistant professor in July 2024. His research explores atomic-scale e
fullText: Suraj Cheema is the AMAX Career Development Assistant Professor in Materials Engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), where he joined the Department of Materials Science and Engineering in July 2024. He holds a joint appointment in the Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science (EECS). Professor Cheema's expertise lies in the intersection of materials science and electrical engineering, with a particular focus on ferroelectrics and their applications in next-generation devices. His research delves into atomic-scale engineering of ferroelectric materials, aiming to unlock their potential for transformative technologies in electronics and energy systems. By investigating the fundamental properties of these materials, Professor Cheema seeks to develop innovative solutions that enhance device performance and efficiency. His work not only contributes to the advancement of materials science but also addresses pressing challenges in the development of sustainable and high-performance electronic devices. Through his research, he aims to bridge the gap between theoretical understanding and practical application, positioning himself as a key contributor to the future of materials engineering.

title: Clarence J Lebel Professor in Electrical Engineering
summary: Magnetic Properties and Interactions of Single-Domain Nanomagnetic Arrays Patterned arrays of single domain nanomagnets (SDNMs) have been proposed as candidates for ultra-high-density data storage and ultra-low-power data processing technology. For both
fullText: Rajeev Ram is the Clarence J. Lebel Professor in Electrical Engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), where he serves as a full professor in the Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science. With a robust academic background and extensive experience in integrated photonics and semiconductor devices, Professor Ram is recognized for his contributions to the fields of microfluidic devices, biopharmaceuticals, and light-emitting diodes. His work is characterized by a deep understanding of the fundamental interactions between electronic materials and light, positioning him as a leading figure in the advancement of innovative technologies. Professor Ram's research primarily focuses on the magnetic properties and interactions of single-domain nanomagnetic arrays, which are being explored as promising candidates for ultra-high-density data storage and ultra-low-power data processing applications. His investigations into patterned arrays of single-domain nanomagnets (SDNMs) have the potential to revolutionize data management and processing technologies. Additionally, he has made significant strides in developing novel semiconductor lasers for advanced fiber optic communications, contributing to the enhancement of communication systems. His expertise spans various domains, including photonics, semiconductor technology, and advanced materials, making him a vital asset in both academia and industry.
tags: Novel Semiconductor Lasers for Advanced Fiber Optic Communications
Study of Fundamental Interactions Between Electronic Materials and Light

title: Joseph F and Nancy P Keithley Professor in Electrical Engineering
summary: Professor Leslie Kolodziejski and Dr. Gale Petrich direct the Integrated Photonics Devices and Materials Research Group and operate the NanoPrecision Deposition Laboratory at MIT. Research conducted in the Integrated Photonics Devices and Materials Resear
fullText: Professor Leslie Kolodziejski serves as the Joseph F. and Nancy P. Keithley Professor in Electrical Engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT). With extensive experience in the field, he leads the Integrated Photonics Devices and Materials Research Group alongside Dr. Gale Petrich, where they focus on advancing the frontiers of photonic and opto-electronic structures. His leadership in the NanoPrecision Deposition Laboratory has positioned him at the cutting edge of research in the development and fabrication of innovative electronic materials and devices. Professor Kolodziejski's research primarily revolves around the epitaxial growth and fabrication of heterostructures and compound semiconductor materials. His work contributes significantly to the understanding and development of opto-electronic devices, showcasing his expertise in heteroepitaxy and novel device physics. Through his research, he aims to enhance the performance and capabilities of photonic devices, making substantial contributions to both academic knowledge and practical applications in the field of electrical engineering. His key areas of expertise include photonic and opto-electronic structures, heteroepitaxial growth, and the development of advanced electronic materials, establishing him as a leading figure in his domain.

Novel Heterostructures
Devices and Device Physics

title: Julius A Stratton Professor of Electrical Engineering
summary: Jeffrey Shapiro is the Julius A.
fullText: Jeffrey Shapiro is the Julius A. Stratton Professor of Electrical Engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), where he has established himself as a leading authority in the fields of optical and quantum communications. With a distinguished academic career, Professor Shapiro's work encompasses a wide range of topics including optical propagation, sensing systems, radar, and atmospheric optical communications. His innovative research has significantly advanced the understanding of entanglement generation at optical frequencies and teleportation, positioning him at the forefront of quantum technology development. In addition to his impressive contributions to theoretical and applied research, Professor Shapiro's expertise extends to the design and implementation of advanced communication systems that leverage the principles of quantum mechanics. His work not only enhances the capabilities of modern communication infrastructures but also addresses critical challenges in the precise transmission of information over long distances. Through his pioneering efforts, Professor Shapiro continues to influence the future trajectory of optical and quantum technologies, fostering collaboration between academia and industry to drive innovation and practical applications.
dlc: Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science

title: Sumitomo Electric Industries Professor in Engineering
summary: Professor Wornell's research interests span several areas of signal processing, communication networks, and information theory, and include algorithms and architectures for wireless networks, broadband systems, and multimedia environments. This research i
fullText: Gregory Wornell is the Sumitomo Electric Industries Professor in Engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), located in Cambridge, Massachusetts. As a full professor, he brings a wealth of knowledge and expertise to the field of engineering, with a particular focus on signal processing, communication networks, and information theory. His extensive academic career is characterized by a commitment to advancing the understanding of algorithms and architectures that enhance the performance of wireless networks, broadband systems, and multimedia environments. Professor Wornell's research contributions are significant and varied, encompassing critical areas such as signal and information manipulation, interference cancellation techniques, multimedia content authentication, and source coding algorithms. His work also delves into the information-theoretic, coding, and algorithmic aspects of inference and learning within communication systems. Through his innovative research, Professor Wornell continues to shape the future of communication technologies, making substantial impacts in both academic and practical applications.
dlc: Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science

title: Eaton-Peabody Professor of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science
summary: Professor Adalsteinsson's current research interests include algorithms and hardware for parallel transmission (pTx), quantitative estimation and management of local power deposition and temperature in MRI, imaging of the fetus and placenta, oxygenation p
fullText: Elfar Adalsteinsson is the Eaton-Peabody Professor of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), located in Cambridge, Massachusetts. With a distinguished career as a full professor, he brings a wealth of knowledge and expertise in the field of medical imaging, specifically focusing on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). Professor Adalsteinsson is recognized for his innovative work in developing algorithms and hardware for parallel transmission (pTx), which has significantly advanced the capabilities of MRI technology. His research also emphasizes the quantitative estimation and management of local power deposition and temperature during MRI procedures, enhancing the safety and efficacy of imaging practices. In addition to his contributions to MRI technology, Professor Adalsteinsson's research encompasses a variety of key areas, including neuro-imaging, chemical shift imaging, and methods for optimal acquisition and processing of in vivo imaging data. His work has been instrumental in improving imaging techniques for critical applications, such as the assessment of fetal and placental health, as well as the early detection and monitoring of neurodegenerative diseases like Alzheimer's. With a strong foundation in data sampling, special encoding, and low-level signals, Professor Adalsteinsson continues to push the boundaries of medical imaging, contributing valuable insights that have far-reaching implications for both research and clinical practice.
tags: and Processing of Imaging Data Acquired In Vivo
dlc: Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science

title: Professor of Electrical Engineering
summary: Jing Kong is a Professor of Electrical Engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), located in Cambridge, Massachusetts.
fullText: Jing Kong is a Professor of Electrical Engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), located in Cambridge, Massachusetts. With a distinguished career in the field of nanotechnology, Professor Kong specializes in the development and application of carbon nanotubes and semiconductor nanowires, focusing on their integration into advanced electronic devices. Her expertise encompasses a broad range of topics, including organic molecules, chemical sensors, and the intricate phenomena of electron transport within one-dimensional interacting systems. Professor Kong's research contributions are pivotal in advancing the understanding of chemical vapor deposition methods and quantum transport phenomena, which are essential for the fabrication and optimization of nanoelectronic components. Additionally, she explores the use of graphene electrodes in various applications, further enhancing the performance and capabilities of electronic devices. Through her innovative work, she has significantly influenced the fields of nanotechnology and materials science, making her a key figure in fostering interdisciplinary collaborations that bridge electrical engineering with emerging technologies.
dlc: Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science

title: Research Affiliate
summary: Charlotte Reed is a Research Affiliate at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where she focuses on innovative solutions and advancements in the field of hearing impairment and deafness.
fullText: Charlotte Reed is a Research Affiliate at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where she focuses on innovative solutions and advancements in the field of hearing impairment and deafness. With a strong background in speech communication, Charlotte dedicates her research to exploring the intricacies of auditory processing and the development of assistive technologies, including hearing aids and tactile aids. Her work aims to enhance the quality of life for individuals with hearing challenges by improving sensory communication and integrating multi-sensory approaches. Charlotte's expertise encompasses a broad range of topics within her field, including the simulation of hearing loss, the tactile sense, and multi-sensory integration. Through her research, she contributes valuable insights into how individuals with hearing impairments perceive and interact with their environment, ultimately striving to create more effective communication tools. Her commitment to advancing the understanding of sensory communication positions her as a key contributor to ongoing research initiatives at MIT and in the broader academic community.

title: Joan and Irwin Jacobs Professor of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science and Aeronautics and Aeronautics
summary: Professor Chan’s current research focus is on the architecture aspect of optical networks, cognitive heterogeneous network management and control, resiliency and security. He is the 2024 recipient of the IEEE Thomas Edison Medal for “pioneering technical
fullText: Vincent Chan is the Joan and Irwin Jacobs Professor of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science and Aeronautics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), located in Cambridge, Massachusetts. As a full professor, he brings extensive expertise in optical networks, satellite networks, and proactive wireless networks, along with a deep understanding of architecture, technology, system designs, and testbed implementations. His work not only contributes to academic advancements but also plays a vital role in shaping the future of communication technologies and network systems. Currently, Professor Chan's research focuses on the architecture of optical networks, cognitive heterogeneous network management and control, as well as resiliency and security measures within these systems. His innovative contributions have garnered significant recognition, culminating in the prestigious IEEE Thomas Edison Medal for 2024, awarded for his pioneering technical advancements in the field. With a strong commitment to developing new communication and network technologies, Professor Chan continues to lead research that addresses critical challenges in optical, wireless, and space communications and networks, positioning him as a key figure in the evolution of modern communication infrastructures.

title: School of Engineering Distinguished Professor for AI and Health
summary: Regina Barzilay is a distinguished professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's School of Engineering, where she holds the title of Distinguished Professor for AI and Health.
fullText: Regina Barzilay is a distinguished professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's School of Engineering, where she holds the title of Distinguished Professor for AI and Health. Based in Cambridge, Massachusetts, Professor Barzilay is a prominent figure in the fields of language and learning, specializing in natural language processing, computer text recognition, and big data analytics. Her work bridges the gap between artificial intelligence and healthcare, emphasizing the transformative potential of AI technologies in improving health outcomes and enhancing patient care. Professor Barzilay's research contributions have significantly advanced the understanding of how language and machine learning can be harnessed to solve complex problems. She has developed innovative algorithms that improve the extraction and interpretation of information from unstructured data sources, thereby enabling better decision-making in medical contexts. Her expertise in natural language processing not only underscores her leadership in AI but also positions her at the forefront of interdisciplinary collaboration, where her insights are instrumental in tackling challenges across various domains within engineering and healthcare.

title: HST Affiliated Faculty
summary: The overarching goal of the Gaiha Lab is to translate insights from successful human T cell responses into effective T cell-based vaccines for infectious disease and cancer. The Gaiha Lab is working to establish a T cell vaccine platform that incorpora
fullText: Gaurav Gaiha is an Associate Professor affiliated with the Harvard-MIT Program in Health Sciences and Technology (HST). His academic and research endeavors are centered around the intricate dynamics of human T cell responses, with a primary focus on translating these insights into effective T cell-based vaccines aimed at combating infectious diseases and cancer. As a member of the prestigious Gaiha Lab, he leads a team dedicated to pioneering a T cell vaccine platform that effectively incorporates immunological principles to enhance therapeutic outcomes. Dr. Gaiha's work stands at the intersection of immunology and vaccine development, where he employs innovative methodologies to unravel the complexities of T cell behavior in various disease contexts. His contributions to the field are significant, particularly in the development of strategies to harness the power of the immune system for vaccine efficacy. With a robust background in immunology, Dr. Gaiha is committed to advancing scientific knowledge and translating research findings into practical applications that hold promise for improving public health and disease management.
dlc: Harvard-MIT Program in Health Sciences and Technology

title: Associate Professor of Philosophy
summary: Rachel Fraser is an associate professor in the Department of Linguistics and Philosophy. Before coming to MIT, Fraser taught at the University of Oxford, where she also completed her graduate work in philosophy. She has interests in epistemology, language
fullText: Rachel Fraser is an Associate Professor of Philosophy in the Department of Linguistics and Philosophy at MIT. With a strong academic foundation from the University of Oxford, where she not only completed her graduate work but also served as a faculty member, Fraser brings a wealth of knowledge and experience to her role. Her primary research interests lie in epistemology and the philosophy of language, areas in which she has made significant contributions through her scholarly publications and presentations. Fraser's work explores the intricate relationships between language and thought, delving into how linguistic structures can influence our understanding of knowledge and belief. Her investigations often bridge traditional philosophical inquiries with contemporary issues in linguistics, making her insights relevant across multiple disciplines. As a thought leader in her field, she is dedicated to advancing the understanding of how language shapes human cognition and epistemic practices, positioning her as a valuable resource for interdisciplinary collaboration and engagement within the academic and corporate communities.
dlc: Department of Philosophy

title: Senior Research Scientist
summary: John Rice serves as a Senior Research Scientist at MIT, where he specializes in advanced X-ray diagnostics and the intricacies of atomic physics, particularly in relation to highly ionized high-Z materials.
fullText: John Rice serves as a Senior Research Scientist at MIT, where he specializes in advanced X-ray diagnostics and the intricacies of atomic physics, particularly in relation to highly ionized high-Z materials. With a strong background in fusion research, he plays a pivotal role in the SPARC initiative, focusing on understanding and improving the performance of plasma confinement through innovative diagnostic techniques. His research contributions extend to transport experiments conducted on the C-Mod and WEST fusion devices, where he investigates intrinsic rotation, impurity dynamics, and the momentum and energy transport mechanisms within plasma systems. John’s expertise encompasses a wide range of topics within atomic physics, enabling him to address complex challenges in the field of fusion energy. His work not only advances fundamental scientific knowledge but also contributes to the development of technologies aimed at harnessing fusion as a viable energy source for the future.
tags: Transport Experiments on C-Mod and WEST
Atomic Physics of Highly Ionized High Z Materials
dlc: Plasma Science and Fusion Center

title: Senior Research Scientist
summary: Dr. Frenje’s research is conducted in the areas of High-Energy-Density-Plasmas (HEDP), Inertial Confinement Fusion (ICF), and nuclear physics. Together with his students, a wide range of diagnostics are built and used to support of the ICF programs at the
fullText: Dr. Johan Frenje is a Senior Research Scientist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where he specializes in High-Energy-Density Plasmas (HEDP), Inertial Confinement Fusion (ICF), and nuclear physics. With a strong commitment to advancing the field, Dr. Frenje leads a dynamic research team that focuses on developing innovative diagnostics to enhance ICF programs. His work not only contributes to a deeper understanding of plasma behavior under extreme conditions but also plays a critical role in the pursuit of sustainable energy solutions through fusion technology. Dr. Frenje's expertise encompasses a broad array of disciplines, including plasma physics, nuclear instrumentation, and advanced plasma diagnostics. His research is characterized by a hands-on approach, collaborating with students and colleagues to build and implement various diagnostic tools that are essential for experimental validation and analysis in ICF research. Through his contributions, Dr. Frenje has positioned himself as a leader in the field, driving significant advancements in the understanding and application of high-energy-density plasmas for both scientific inquiry and practical energy generation.
dlc: Plasma Science and Fusion Center

title: Head, Magnet Technology Division, Bitter National Magnet Lab
summary: Yukikazu Iwasa serves as the Head of the Magnet Technology Division at the Bitter National Magnet Lab, where he is a Senior Research Scientist with extensive expertise in superconducting magnet technology, cryogenics, and cryogenic engineering.
fullText: Yukikazu Iwasa serves as the Head of the Magnet Technology Division at the Bitter National Magnet Lab, where he is a Senior Research Scientist with extensive expertise in superconducting magnet technology, cryogenics, and cryogenic engineering. In this pivotal role, Iwasa leads a team dedicated to advancing the development and application of high-performance magnets, which are critical for various scientific and industrial applications, including fusion energy research. Iwasa's research focuses on the design and optimization of superconducting magnets, leveraging his deep understanding of cryogenic systems to enhance their efficiency and reliability. His work significantly contributes to the field of fusion magnets, where he explores innovative solutions that address the challenges posed by high magnetic fields and extreme operational conditions. With a robust background in cryogenics, Iwasa is well-regarded for his contributions to both theoretical and practical advancements, making him a key figure in the ongoing pursuit of sustainable energy solutions through advanced magnet technology.
dlc: Plasma Science and Fusion Center

title: Principal Research Scientist, Experimental
summary: Amanda Hubbard serves as a Principal Research Scientist at MIT, where she specializes in experimental research within the field of plasma physics and fusion energy.
fullText: Amanda Hubbard serves as a Principal Research Scientist at MIT, where she specializes in experimental research within the field of plasma physics and fusion energy. With a robust background in tokamak pedestal physics, she is dedicated to advancing the understanding of plasma confinement and stability, which are critical to the development of fusion as a viable energy source. Her leadership in experimental initiatives has positioned her as a key contributor to the ongoing research aimed at achieving sustainable fusion reactions. Hubbard's research encompasses a range of innovative topics, including the VPI solder-filling process for high-temperature superconducting (HTS) magnets, transport barriers, and millimeter-wave diagnostics. She is actively involved in the design and implementation of integrated fusion scenarios that seek to optimize the performance of fusion devices. Amanda's expertise in these areas not only enhances the scientific community's knowledge but also plays a vital role in the practical application of fusion technology, potentially paving the way for cleaner, more abundant energy solutions in the future.
tags: VPI Solder-Filling Process for HTS Magnets
dlc: Plasma Science and Fusion Center

fullText: Kazi Sadia serves as a Senior Policy Associate at J-PAL North America, where she plays a pivotal role in bridging the gap between academic research and practical policy implementation. With a strong commitment to utilizing evidence-based approaches for social change, Kazi collaborates with policymakers and practitioners to influence decision-making processes that enhance the effectiveness of various programs and initiatives. Her work is instrumental in promoting the understanding and application of randomized evaluations, which serve as a cornerstone for assessing the impact of social interventions. Kazi’s contributions to the field are marked by her dedication to improving policy outcomes through rigorous analysis and strategic communication. She specializes in translating complex research findings into actionable insights that can be readily understood and applied by stakeholders in the public sector. Her expertise encompasses a range of topics, including education policy, poverty alleviation, and labor markets, allowing her to provide comprehensive support across diverse policy areas. Kazi's passion for integrating research with real-world applications positions her as a valuable asset to J-PAL North America and the broader community focused on advancing social equity through informed policymaking.

title: Class of 1954 Career Development Associate Professor of Music
summary: An avid chamber musician, Natalie Lin has toured throughout New Zealand in concerts presented by Chamber Music New Zealand and in the UK with the Scottish Ensemble. She has appeared as a guest artist with NZTrio, and performed alongside musicians includin
fullText: Natalie Lin Douglas is the Class of 1954 Career Development Associate Professor of Music at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), where she brings a wealth of experience and expertise in chamber music performance and education. With a passion for collaborative music-making, she has established herself as a prominent figure in the music community, both nationally and internationally. Her role at MIT allows her to engage with students and colleagues in the exploration of music's diverse forms and its cultural significance. An avid chamber musician, Professor Douglas has toured extensively throughout New Zealand, performing in concerts presented by Chamber Music New Zealand, and has also showcased her talent in the UK with the esteemed Scottish Ensemble. Her performances as a guest artist with NZTrio and collaborations with a variety of musicians highlight her commitment to fostering artistic connections and enriching the musical landscape. Through her research and performance endeavors, she continues to contribute to the evolving discourse on chamber music, making significant strides in the understanding and appreciation of this genre.
dlc: Music and Theater Arts

title: Visiting Scientist
summary: Biomaterials science represents the next frontier in medical therapeutics. Innovations in materials design and formulation have helped create interventions and composite devices previously unimaginable with materials whose structure and function evolve wi
fullText: Natalie Artzi serves as a Visiting Scientist at MIT, where she specializes in the field of biomaterials science. With a profound expertise in tissue-biomaterials interactions, Dr. Artzi is dedicated to advancing the understanding of how innovative materials can be designed and formulated to create cutting-edge medical therapeutics. Her research focuses on the development of composite devices and interventions that leverage the evolving structure and function of biomaterials, aiming to address complex medical challenges that were previously deemed unfeasible. Dr. Artzi's contributions to the field have positioned her as a key figure in the exploration of new frontiers in medical technology. By investigating the dynamic relationship between biological tissues and synthetic materials, she seeks to uncover novel solutions that enhance the effectiveness and safety of therapeutic applications. Her work not only reflects her commitment to improving patient outcomes but also contributes significantly to the broader landscape of biomedical engineering and materials science.
dlc: Institute for Medical Engineering and Science
